During the recent parliamentary debate, Communist orators up to the eleventh hour were
denouncing the Trieste settlement as a "sellout" to the United States and the Atlantic
community* Then once ©gain by telling the United Nations the Soviet Union took "due note"

For these reasons, as I say, on© would have expected the Seelba government to emerge
from these four votes of confidence at the peak of its popularity and prestige. And there
were other factors in the Italian political picture which ordinarily would serve to streng¬
then the government at this point.
On the foreign policy front there were the London and Faria conferences of the nine
Atlantic community nations, which produced more than many Italians expected, after the
killing of the European Defense Community in the French National assembly.
These agreements, for giving sovereignty and eventually arms to West Germany, and for * V
bringing that republic and Italy into the Brussels treaty seemed to be favorably received by
Italians. They were something of a political victory for a new Liberal foreign minister,
Gaetano Martino, who seems to be making a substantial impression on the Italian public.
On the domestic front, there were evidences this autumn of a gradual upturn in the
Italian economy. It was nothing to be jubilant about, and economists doubted that it would
make any substantial dent in the hard core of 2,300,000 unemployed in the near future. But
there was a quickening of the economic pace in Italy and an alert government might have
turned it to political advantage.
I have already cited the demonstrated ability of the four democratic parties to hang
together to protect the government’s narrow parliamentary majority. But there was a negative
political factor this autumn that also served to ease the government’s situation. During the
summer, the long-anticipated split in the Monarchist party became a fact. The mayor of
Naples, Achilla Lauro, who had been president of the National Monarchist party and chief
contributor to its treasury, resigned and formed a new group called the Popular Monarchist
party. The bulk of the Monarchist members of parliament remained loyal to the old party and
its secretary, 'Ifredo Covelli, Lauro*s bitter enemy. But lauro did manage to take a few
Monarchist parliamentarians with him* This Monarchist split was reflected in the majorities
achieved by Signor Seelba in those four confidence votes I have cited.
The old Monarchist party, as usual, took an official stand against the government. But
when the senate voted on the Trieste issue, one Monarchist voted for the government and 14
others left the chamber to avoid taking a stand. Seven Monarchists abstained in one of the
votes in the chamber of deputies and on the other occasion several of them supported Signor
Seelba.
To sum up, while the democratic party lines were holding fast, the pressure against the
government from the political right was lessening somewhat because of the split in Monarchist
ranks.
These, then, were fairly Impressive assets for a hard-pressed government* the return
of Triestef moderate new success for Italy’s pro-European, pro-Atlantic community foreign
